title: 108_hr257
content: The Act titled "Emergency Agricultural Disaster Assistance Act of 2003" provides crop disaster assistance. The Emergency Agricultural Disaster Assistance Act of 2003 provides crop disaster assistance through the use of funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation for producers who have incurred qualifying crop losses due to damaging weather conditions. Assistance is administered in a similar manner as provided in the Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 2001. Additionally, assistance for livestock producers is also available. The Secretary of Agriculture will use funds from the Commodity Credit Corporation to provide assistance to livestock producers in counties designated as primary disaster areas in 2001 or 2002. Producers can apply for assistance within 30 days of the enactment of the Act, following criteria from the 2002 Livestock Compensation Program. Producers in designated counties in 2001 or 2002 can receive payments for losses in either year, not both. They cannot receive payments from both this section and the 2002 Livestock Compensation Program. Producers in designated counties in 2001 or 2002 are ineligible for payments from both this section and the 2002 Livestock Compensation Program. In this section, definitions are provided for terms like additional coverage, insurable commodity, and noninsurable commodity. Producers on a farm are ineligible for payments under certain conditions. Producers on a farm are ineligible for payments for 2002 losses to insurable or noninsurable commodities if they did not obtain insurance or file required paperwork and pay fees by the deadline. The Secretary of Agriculture may waive these requirements under certain circumstances. Producers on a farm must enter into contracts with the Secretary for insurable commodities to obtain additional coverage for the next three crops under the Federal Crop Insurance Act. They must also agree to forfeit any payments or benefits under the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act for violating the contract. For noninsurable commodities, producers must file required paperwork and pay fees as per the contract with the Secretary. To receive additional coverage for the next three crops under the Federal Crop Insurance Act, producers must enter contracts with the Secretary for insurable commodities. They must also agree to forfeit any payments or benefits under the Farm Security and Rural Investment Act if the contract is violated. For noninsurable commodities, producers must file paperwork and pay fees by the State filing deadline. The Secretary of Agriculture will utilize the Commodity Credit Corporation's resources to implement the Act. Regulations will also be established. The Secretary of Agriculture may issue necessary regulations to implement the Act without following certain procedural requirements. This includes bypassing notice and comment provisions and the Paperwork Reduction Act. Congressional review of agency rulemaking will be conducted under specified authority. Additionally, emergency designation provisions are included in the Act. SEC. 7. EMERGENCY DESIGNATION. The entire amount made available under this Act shall be available only if the President submits an official budget request designating it as an emergency requirement for the Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985. Congress designates the amount as an emergency requirement under specific sections of the Act.
